segments.text: Where could I get politically involved?
So I wrote letters to all of the clubs explaining to them about the University Fund.
So I get this letter from this lawyer in Divine or Pleasant, and I forget.
He says, I was starting up a
a gossip about the Permanent University Fund that never could be, nothing had been said about it.
And somebody from that club had given him the letter
So then I called Mr. Cherry and read him the letter.
And he said, well, Ms. Gonzalez, he's a lawyer.
He should know.
And I said, well, this is what he wrote me.
So I drove up here, met with Mr. Cherry, and he said, well, what can we do?

I said, you need to write up what the permanent university fund is, what it will do if they break it, and put a little brochure and send it to all the former students, and then put it on the Texas Aggie.
So that's what we did.
I still have some of those flyers that they were sent home.
And boy, they started.
And at that time I was working on, Martha Neese from the Valley and I were working on the library bill to have standards to have a library for so many students in each school.
And the senator from Conroe was working with us because his wife was a librarian.
And he had been, he had lost a leg in Vietnam and the assistant to Clemens at that time had lost a leg and they were good friends.
So we were working on a library bill, and I was going, having to go to Austin and Martha Neese and several other librarians to draw up a bill with this senator.
And we worked on that, and we worked on the Permanent University Fund.
We'd take cookies to some of the legislators.
And we finally got that, Mr.
Chair and I, in talking, finally got it, you know, they didn't break it.
And we got our library bill through, and I said, oh, never again.
Now, what led you to be library concerned?
Librarian?
Ever since I was a little girl, I always wanted to be a librarian.
All right.
And that led you to be interested in A&M's library?
Oh, yes.
I served on the library council.
If you were giving advice to Texas A&M's leaders now about today and the future of A&M, what advice would you give them?
I would tell them that academics are stressed, loyalty is stressed, but I think
The thing that they should keep in mind is where A&M came from.
That's what they should stress to the students, how A&M evolved and what sacrifices were made to have A&M.
And not just rest on the glory right now of being a great university.
How did it come to be that great university?
See, that's what we're trying to learn more of this.
Well I'm about finished.
Can you think of anything we've left out?
No, like I said, don't let A&M lose its traditions.
Keep the students informed on how A&M is about to be this great university.
What difference has it made in your life that your brother and your husband and your son attended Texas A&M?
Well, it has made me very proud to be a sister of, well, my seven brothers came here.
My oldest brother worked for A&M Experiment Station for 50 years as an agronomer, and he's truly naggy.
I have, of course, my husband and my son.
I have four nieces that graduated from A&M and four nephews that have graduated.
And they have given us the opportunity and given them the opportunity to become very productive citizens and outstanding.

All right, then the next last question is, what if someone walked up to you and gave you a check for a million dollars with one restriction, that you have to pass that check on to Texas A&M, but you can decide the use A&M is to make of that check.
If you could be very, very, very generous to A&M, what would you want your gift to do?
I would like my gift to do to expand the library, expand the programs here at the Memorial Student Center and the School for Teaching Excellence.
And in the library, any particular thing you'd want them to do?
Well, just to where they could buy more books.
More reading material.
I think we're stressing technology too much.
People need to sit and read and lose themselves in a book, not just punch machines.
Last question.
What feelings do you carry in your heart about Texas A&M?
It's just wonderful feelings, a feeling of pride.
a feeling that I have been part of A&M, and a feeling that we were welcome here at A&M.
That's a good ending.
